Authors:
Rosario Gregorio-Cipriano, Dolores González, Rubén
Félix-Gastélum, Santiago Chacón
Title:
Morphological and molecular identification of new records and
new host plants of powdery mildews (Erysiphales) from Mexico
Keywords:
powdery mildew, cucurbits, Podosphaera xanthii,
Golovinomyces ambrosiae, Neoerysiphe sechii
Abstract:
Golovinomyces ambrosiae, Neoerysiphe sechii, and
Podosphaera xanthii, associated with cultivated and wild cucurbits in
three producing regions were identified in Mexico. Leaf samples of
cultivated and wild cucurbits species or subspecies showing symptoms and
signs of powdery mildew were collected from the north-western,
central-western, and eastern regions of Mexico from November 2017
through November 2020. Species associated with the disease were
identified by morphological features and sequences from the ITS
(ITS1-5.8S-ITS2). All the specimens of powdery mildew presented only the
anamorphic phase. Podosphaera xanthii was the predominant species since
it was found in 85.7% of the samples analyzed in all three regions in
Mexico, and 13 out of 14 species or subspecies of cucurbits studied.
Neoerysiphe sechii was found only in four species of cucurbits
representing 15.23% of the samples analyzed. These host species occurred
in the central-western and eastern regions of the country. Golovinomyces
ambrosiae is documented for the first time on a Cucurbitaceae (Sicyos
deppei) from central-western Mexico. New hosts are also registered for
N. sechii and P. xanthii in Mexico
